articles.headline: Flooding Chaos in Yellowstone, a Sign of Crises to Come
articles.snippet: Record rainfall and mudslides forced closures just as tourism season ramped up. Virtually none of America’s national parks are untouched by extreme weather and climate change.
articles.abstract: Record rainfall and mudslides forced closures just as tourism season ramped up. Virtually none of America’s national parks are untouched by extreme weather and climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARDINER, Mont. — Before evacuating their rental cabin on the edge of Yellowstone National Park, the Manning family watched a nearby house plunge from the riverbank into the raging, flood-swollen waters.
articles.byline: By Jim Robbins, Thomas Fuller and Christine Chung

articles.headline: Inside a Corporate Culture War Stoked by a Crypto C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Jesse Powell, who leads the crypto exchange Kraken, has challenged the use of preferred pronouns, debated who can use racial slurs and called American women “brainwashed.”
articles.abstract: Jesse Powell, who leads the crypto exchange Kraken, has challenged the use of preferred pronouns, debated who can use racial slurs and called American women “brainwashed.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Jesse Powell, a founder and the chief executive of Kraken, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchanges, recently asked his employees, “If you can identify as a sex, can you identify as a race or ethnicity?”
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: U.S. and Allies Pledge Additional Arms for Ukraine, but Kyiv Wants More
articles.snippet: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
articles.abstract: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Biden on Wednesday announced a further $1 billion in weapons and aid for Ukraine, as the United States and its allies met to craft a response to Ukraine’s increasingly urgent calls for advanced arms to beat back Russia’s invasion.

articles.headline: Trump Lawyer Cited ‘Heated Fight’ Among Justices Over Election Suits
articles.snippet: In an email weeks after the election, another lawyer advising the Trump campaign responded that the prospect of “‘wild’ chaos” on Jan. 6 could lead the Supreme Court to take up a case.
articles.abstract: In an email weeks after the election, another lawyer advising the Trump campaign responded that the prospect of “‘wild’ chaos” on Jan. 6 could lead the Supreme Court to take up a case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Pfizer and Moderna Vaccines for Youngest Children
articles.snippet: States have already ordered millions of doses; if the agency authorizes them in the coming days, babies, toddlers and preschoolers could start receiving shots next week.
articles.abstract: States have already ordered millions of doses; if the agency authorizes them in the coming days, babies, toddlers and preschoolers could start receiving shots next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The only Americans still not eligible for coronavirus vaccines — babies, toddlers and preschoolers — appear on the verge of finally getting cleared to receive them after an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines for the group.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Ukraine’s Highly Mobile Tech Work Force Hits the Road
articles.snippet: How one Lithuanian company evacuated dozens of employees, three dogs and one guinea pig as Russia invaded.
articles.abstract: How one Lithuanian company evacuated dozens of employees, three dogs and one guinea pig as Russia invaded.
articles.lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — In the mobile game Airplane Chefs, the player is a flight attendant rushing to microwave as much food as possible and serve it, just as efficiently, on a commercial jet filled with demanding passengers.

articles.headline: Democrats’ Risky Bet: Aid G.O.P. Extremists in Spring, Hoping to Beat Them in Fall
articles.snippet: As Democratic leaders warn loudly of right-wing threats to democracy, their campaign arms are meddling in Republican primaries, betting they can help pick easier opponents in November.
articles.abstract: As Democratic leaders warn loudly of right-wing threats to democracy, their campaign arms are meddling in Republican primaries, betting they can help pick easier opponents in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as national Democrats set off alarms over the threats posed by far-right Republican candidates, their campaign partners are pursuing an enormously risky strategy: promoting some of those same far-right candidates in G.O.P. primaries in hopes that extremists will be easier for Democrats to beat in November.

articles.headline: How a Religious Sect Landed Google in a Lawsuit
articles.snippet: A video producer claims he was fired after he complained that an obscure group based in the Sierra foothills dominated a business unit at Google.
articles.abstract: A video producer claims he was fired after he complained that an obscure group based in the Sierra foothills dominated a business unit at Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: OREGON HOUSE, Calif. — In a tiny town in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, a religious organization called the Fellowship of Friends has established an elaborate, 1,200-acre compound full of art and ornate architecture.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Wall Street shudders as focus returns to recession risks.
articles.snippet: Stocks tumbled, with the S&P 500 falling further into bear market territory, as investors focused on the threat that inflation and higher interest rates pose to the economy.
articles.abstract: Stocks tumbled, with the S&P 500 falling further into bear market territory, as investors focused on the threat that inflation and higher interest rates pose to the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, investors took comfort that the Federal Reserve would do whatever was necessary to bring inflation to heel, responding to the rallying cry of the Fed chair, Jerome H. Powell, by pushing stock prices up.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Isabella Simonetti

articles.headline: Trump, Told It Was Illegal, Still Pressured Pence to Overturn His Loss
articles.snippet: In its third public hearing to lay out its findings, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack showed evidence that the president knew his order to the vice president was unlawful.
articles.abstract: In its third public hearing to lay out its findings, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack showed evidence that the president knew his order to the vice president was unlawful.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Donald J. Trump continued pressuring Vice President Mike Pence to go along with a plan to unilaterally overturn his election defeat even after he was told it was illegal, according to testimony laid out in extensive detail on Thursday by the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Revlon, a Makeup Staple for Generations, Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The company has struggled to attract younger shoppers who are choosing celebrity makeup lines like those from Kylie Jenner and Rihanna.
articles.abstract: The company has struggled to attract younger shoppers who are choosing celebrity makeup lines like those from Kylie Jenner and Rihanna.
articles.lead_paragraph: For generations of women, Revlon’s red Fire & Ice, introduced in 1952, was the go-to lipstick shade on a Saturday night.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Julie Creswell
